questions.text: Which of the following is not a paranasal sinus?
questions.solution:
Pyriform sinus (fossa) is a part of hypopharynx. It lies on either side of the larynx and extends from pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of oesophagus.

Sinuses are air-containing cavities in certain bones of skull.

It is divided into 2 groups.

Anterior group includes

  • Maxillary
  • Frontal
  • Anterior ethmoidal sinuses.

Posterior group includes

  • Posterior ethmoid
  • Sphenoid sinuses.

questions.text: Which is the largest paranasal sinus?
questions.solution: Maxillary sinus is the largest of paranasal sinuses and occupies the body of maxilla.

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as antrum of Highmore?
questions.solution: Maxillary sinus is also known as antrum of Highmore.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the maxillary sinus?

choices.text: Pyramidal in shape with base towards lateral wall of nose and apex towards zygomatic arch
Pyramidal in shape with base towards zygomatic arch and apex towards lateral wall of nose.

questions.solution: Maxillary sinus is pyramidal in shape, with base towards lateral wall of nose and apex directed laterally into the zygomatic process of maxilla and sometimes in the zygomatic bone itself.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the specimen of a maxillectomy. Which of the following epithelium do you expect to find lining the maxillary sinus?
questions.solution: Paranasal sinuses are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells which secrete mucus. They're lined by the mucous membrane, which is continuous with that of the nasal cavity through the ostia of sinuses.

questions.text: Which of the following is most superior in location?
questions.solution:
Frontal sinus is the most superiorly located sinus.
It is situated between the inner and outer tables of frontal bone, above and deep to the supraorbital margin.

questions.text: An anxious father brings his newborn baby to the pediatrician after dropping his baby when shifting from one arm to another. The pediatrician orders a CT head, which is normal. Which of the following structures would you not expect to find in the CT?
questions.solution:
The frontal sinus is absent or rudimentary at birth. Radiologically, the frontal sinus is able to be identified at 6 years and reaches full size only after puberty. 

At birth, only the maxillary and ethmoidal sinuses are present and are large enough to be clinically significant. Sphenoid sinus, though may be present, is usually undeveloped and non-aerated.

Sinuses At birth First radiological evidence Reaches adult size by
Maxillary Present 4-5 months after birth 15 years
Ethmoidal Present 1 year 12 years
Frontal Absent/rudimentary 6 years Post-puberty
Sphenoid Present 4 years 14 years

questions.text: Where does the posterior ethmoidal sinus open?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal sinus opens into the superior meatus.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is true about sphenoid sinus?

choices.text: Present in greater wing of sphenoid
Lateral wall is related to the pituitary gland

questions.solution:
Sphenoid sinus opens into sphenoethmoidal recess.

Related Pearl: The sphenoid sinus

It occupies the body of the sphenoid

Ostium of the sphenoid sinus is situated high up in the anterior wall and opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, medial to the superior or supreme turbinate

It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Cilia are more marked near the ostium, which facilitates mucus drainage into the nasal cavity

Relations of the sphenoid sinus:

  • The lateral wall of the sphenoid is related to the optic nerve and carotid artery
  • The floor of the sinus is related to the Vidian nerve
  • The anterior part of the roof is related to the olfactory tract, optic chiasma, and frontal lobe
  • The posterior part is related to the pituitary gland in the sella turcica and the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident performing endoscopic biopsy from the sphenoid sinus in a COVID patient with suspected mucormycosis. Through which of the following areas will you access the sinus?
questions.solution:
The sphenoid sinus is accessed through the sphenoethmoidal recess which is situated above the superior turbinate.

The ostium of the sphenoid sinus can be located endoscopically 1cm above the upper margin of the posterior choana near the posterior border of the septum.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

Related Pearl: The sphenoid sinus

It occupies the body of the sphenoid

Ostium of the sphenoid sinus is situated high up in the anterior wall and opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, medial to the superior or supreme turbinate

It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Cilia are more marked near the ostium, which facilitates mucus drainage into the nasal cavity

Relations of the sphenoid sinus:

  • The lateral wall of the sphenoid is related to the optic nerve and carotid artery
  • The floor of the sinus is related to the Vidian nerve
  • The anterior part of the roof is related to the olfactory tract, optic chiasma, and frontal lobe
  • The posterior part is related to the pituitary gland in the sella turcica and the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to removal of which of the following ethmoidal cells?
questions.solution:
Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells.

Option A: Haller cells are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis.

Option B: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinates.

Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process and forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain.

questions.text: While performing functional endoscopic sinus surgery,  the surgeon points out the Haller cells and their clinical significance. Which of the following is correct about these cells?

choices.text: They are related to the maxillary sinus
They are related to the optic nerve
They are related to the sphenoid sinus
They are related to the facial nerve

questions.solution:
Haller cells (infraorbital ethmoidal air cells) are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated in the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis.

The star-marked area in the given CT scan shows the Haller cell

questions.text: What is occipitomental view with open mouth also known as?
questions.solution:
Occipitomental view is called Water's view. Water's view with an open mouth is known as Pierre's view. Among the given options, Water's view is the best answer.

In Water's view, the patient’s head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward. The mouth is usually kept open, which allows visualizing the sphenoid sinus. 

Structures seen in Water’s view are:

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of the maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

Other options: 

Option B: Towne's view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull. Structures seen are the petrous part of the pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum, internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis. 

Option C: Law's view is a lateral oblique X-ray view of the mastoid. Structures seen are the external auditory canal, mastoid air cells, tegmen, lateral sinus plate, and temporomandibular joint. 

Option D: Stenver's view is an X-ray view of the skull where the long axis of the petrous bone is parallel to the film. Structures seen are the entire petrous pyramid, arcuate eminence, internal auditory meatus, labyrinth with its vestibule, cochlea, and mastoid antrum. 

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid
